It would make so much more sense if these suggested synonyms appear in the suggested edits review queue. After all, tag wiki edits appear there.

Can this be done?

Title: Is it illegal to quote the C++ Standard Draft?
Body:
I recently edited an answer from another StackOverflow user in order to clarify some parts it by adding some quotes from the C++14 Standard Working Draft (N4296) - the user however rolled back my edit immediately and told me to "not add copyrighted text" to the answer.

Am I infringing the copyright (and committing a crime) when citing the Standard Working Draft? I've seen many answers containing quotes from the Standard Working Draft on StackOveflow before, and I also think it would be really unfortunate to be unable to cite it.

Does citing the Standard Working Draft fall under "Fair Use" for nonprofit educational uses? Or should I avoid doing it and edit out answers that cite the Standard Working Draft?

Title: Stack Overflow code snippet tool bug: `console.log` incorrectly reports missing array slot as undefined
Body:
The Stack Overflow code snippet tool produces an ambiguous and, depending on your definitions, incorrect output when using the JavaScript console.log command with an array that has missing slots, i.e. a sparse array.

I show below screen-shots of the input and output for using console.log([undefined,,4]) from within the Stack Exchange code snippet tool as well as from within the browser consoles of various common browsers.

Stack Overflow code snippet tool input:

Stack Overflow code snippet tool output:

Note that in this output the first and second elements are shown identically, i.e. as undefined.

The identical command shows the following output in the browser consoles in Chrome, Firefox, Safari and Opera:

Chrome:

Firefox:

Safari:

Opera:

In each of these browser consoles the output is unambiguous and correct. Specifically, only the first element is reported as undefined and the element with index 1 is shown as missing/non-existent. In contrast, the output from within the code snippet tool is at least confusing/misleading if not technically incorrect (depending on how you define what the output of console.log should be).

I believe that the output of console.log in the code snippet tool should mirror the output from the browser consoles with respect to reporting missing slots in JavaScript sparse arrays, both because it will be clearer and because it will be consistent with browser console output.

Note that the above analysis did not include Internet Explorer 11 which has its own bug related to this issue. Just so responders don't waste their energy pursuing this, I show the IE11 bug here, when I try to show the same thing in the IE11 console. Note the doubling up of the element with index 2, which is reported as both undefined and as 4, which is clearly wrong.

Title: Main site suspensions to refresh chat profiles
Body:
Currently, for actively chatting users, if a moderator suspends on main, they have to manually refresh the chat profile of the offending user. Until they do, said user still has chat privileges.

Could a suspension automatically cause the chat profile associated with the user to refresh from parent?

Title: Flair HTML snippet refers to HTTP image src, causes mixed content warning on HTTPS site
Body:
I used the Flair HTML snippet from my profile settings on my website, but I noticed that it caused Chrome to report a mixed content warning. It turns out that the image src is pointing to an HTTP resource, not an HTTPS one.

I updated my snippet code and all is good now, but the code should be like this by default.

Title: Missing tag descriptions on random tags in tags page
Body:
In the tags page, the description and question count of some tags are missing. This also happens when these tags are searched. They seem to be random.

Is this a bug or an intended feature?

Title: Disallow voting from accounts which are pending deletion?
Body:
If a user's account is scheduled for deletion (i.e. they've submitted a formal request for account deletion, but the button hasn't actually been pressed yet), can they be prevented from voting?

I can't see any reason why such a user should be allowed to continue casting votes on the site. They've already decided that they're soon going to be a non-user, and they won't be able to vote at that point anyway; and if they really want to continue voting, all they have to do is cancel the deletion.

On the other hand, there are sometimes good reasons why they shouldn't be allowed to vote in this period. In many cases (not all), a user deleting their account is in the middle of some sort of "rage quit", and an obvious thing for a ragequitting user to do would be to leave a bunch of downvotes before they go, as a form of hitting on the break. If they do it soon enough before the deletion, they might even be able to get away with doing things which would normally be reversed by the serial voting algorithm. Or, worse, they could unaccept answers to all their questions - downvotes can be invalidated by SE employees, but nobody except the OP can re-add checkmarks to answers. For that matter, even the standard ragequitter practice of deleting all their posts could count as a sort of voting - it's disabled during account suspension, so why not during pending deletion periods too?

Title: Pundit badge: Do moved comments count?
Body: I wrote a comment on a question and was getting up votes, 13 last time I was able to check. I later logged in to see how many votes it had (This was the first time one of my comments had gotten a bunch of upvotes, so I was excitingly tracking it), and was disappointed that my +13 comment had been moved to chat because others had been discussing the question. My question is: Will that ex-comment count towards the pundit badge? Also, out of curiosity, do mods have to move all the comments when they move comments?

Title: Is it good or bad style to ask for help?
Body:
I wonder whether I should end a question on SO with a polite phrase asking or thanking in advance for help, such as:

  • “Any help is apreciated.”
  • “Thanks in advance for any help.”
  • “Any advice on how to tackle this?”

Or should I let that be and just type in my question? Is there consensus on this topic or a policy I did’t find yet?

When editing ugly questions (bad markup, or typos), should I add or remove such a phrase at the end?

Title: Is there a SEDE query that finds all questions that I asked and answered myself?
Body:
I'm looking for a particular question that I answered myself, because I want to find a meta-discussion in the comments about whether that's okay (spoiler: it is).

Has anyone written a query that will find those questions for me?

Title: Is it ok to down vote an answer to a poorly written question?
Body:
I recently came across a post that basically asked "How do I do X?". No research effort, code, or any other details provided. Myself and a few others commented for more information. A few minutes later someone answered the question with code.

I down voted the answer and commented because I feel like answering a question like this only encourages people to ask these types of poorly written, undetailed questions.

Am I wrong for down voting the answer?

Title: Would like a histogram option added to Stack Exchange Data Explorer
Body: Looking at the Help link on Stack Exchange Data explorer, I don't see any way to create a horizontally scrollable histogram. I want to develop queries that could let's say, show how many votes I got for answers for various tags at various points along a time scale for example, or even for specific questions, and the x vs. y curve graph doesn't accommodate that.

Title: Remove extra "Version" word from auto generated info in the iOS app
Body:
When you submitting a bug for (and from) iOS app, app automatically adds information block to the post's body, e.g.:

As you can see word "Version" is doubling in OS section. I suggest to remove one of these, as I already did manually in current post.

  • App Version: 1.6.4
  • Device: iPad Air 2 (Wi-Fi)
  • OS Version: 10.2.1 (Build 14D27)

Title: Fixed sorting choice for all communities
Body: I usually like to navigate through different sites. When I do so, I usually sort the questions with respect to number of upvotes. In Android app, when I pick my sorting choice, it is applied to all sites. The same feature in iOS would also be very convenient.

Title: Rephrase "Edit answers and questions" privilege
Body:
The current 2k reputation privilege says "Edit questions and answers".

However, the power to edit questions or answers have already been granted way before 2000 reputation is earned -- these edits simply are not applied immediately and instead require a review.

So, I propose a rephrase for the 2k reputation to clarify the difference of the immediate effects of an edit, something like "Apply edits immediately", to avoid confusion.

Title: Default drag-and-drop image upload captions to the filename
Body:
After dropping an image into the "Drag and drop or click here" window, SE uploads it, but the image caption in the generated Markdown will still be the default "enter image description here"

GitHub does this better by defaulting the image to the filename. When users save screenshots, they may give them descriptive filenames, and it would save a bunch of typing if that filename was imported as the image description.

Title: Blog post "spams" feed
Body:
When I refresh my feed in the stack exchange Android app, I'll get everytime a new blog post entry about stack overflows top navigation. That's annoying and I don't think it is how it should be.

App version: 1.0.89
Samsung Galaxy S5-mini
Android: 5.1.1

Title: What is the "Participation" user sort on Meta sites?
Body:
I notice that users on per-site metas are, by default, sorted by something called "participation". I would assume this to be Meta-pseudo-rep, but it seems that someone who has basically no Meta activity and pretty much only votes can hold 2nd place in this sort.

  • What is the formula for this?
  • Why can't it be adjusted for different timeframes (e.g. week, month,
  • Can we have this sort on main sites?

Title: Redesign of header on SE sites
Body: Stack Overflow, as we know, switched to a new header design. When will redesigned header be avaliable for all Q/As?

Title: Comment owner should be notified if comment is flagged as obsolete (not otherwise)
Body:
Frequently, I suggest a post author to make a particular change. The author makes the change, then notified me in a comment to inform me. I delete my comment (which is now obsolete) and flag the other comment for being obsolete as well. Then a moderator needs to come along, verify the comment is indeed obsolete, and delete it.

The moderator workload would be reduced significantly if the comment author was notified as well. The comment author will probably have the conversation in fresh memory.

Title: Show us past community events from newest to oldest
Body:
When viewing past community events at /admin/community-events?tab=past (as often happens to copy one for modification and reuse) the list shows up in oldest to newest order.

This is not helpful since I'm not usually looking for random things from 5 years ago, but rather something more recent.

I don't see any way to switch the ordering back and forth, and I don't think that is such a useful feature anyway, but the default should be most recent events first, unlike the current implementation.

Title: Incorrect side-by-side visual diff when adding ` characters to links
Body: In https://unix.stackexchange.com/posts/345508/revisions, a user edited my post to, among other things, have ` characters. The side-by-side Markdown diff shows that [the zsh manual][1] was changed to have ` characters around "zsh", but the visual side-by-side diff shows that "manual" was changed in addition to "zsh".

Title: Display names are cut off on the Top Apps and Top Scripts pages
Body: Using Firefox 51.0.1 on Windows 10. See the screenshot below:

Title: Display all tags on the Top Apps and Top Scripts pages
Body: Only two tags are visible currently, even when there are more tags. Please display all tags. See the screenshot below:

Title: Posting an answer after posting it in comment that solved the OP's problem
Body:
The solution to the OP's problem was pretty simple, I posted my suggestion in the comment section and it worked out for them (I just didn't expect it to be so simple, that's why I commented instead of answering).

The question is, should I post my suggestion as an answer now so it would be more visible (and so I would hopefully get some reputation, heheh), or is it a bad practice and I should leave it as-is?

Title: Weird. My Flair now reports the rep from ALL of my SE sites
Body:
I just noticed that my flair no longer shows just the pictures and summed reputation from sites that I have 200+ rep. Instead, it's summing the reputation from all of my registered sites (and showing as many site pictures as it can fit), regardless of my total reputation at those sites.

However, the flair page still says:

please note that only sites where you have more than 200 reputation will appear

My flair was not doing this as of earlier this week.

Is this a bug or did the policy/mechanics of how flair works change?

Title: When comments are flagged, and the user is destroyed, the flags remain
Body:
This is an obscure bug that only can be seen by moderators. I found a flag on a few comments of a user that were just spam. When I looked at the user, it was obvious he was only created to spam, and I destroyed the user's account, as is usually done for such people. The comments are now deleted, however, the flags still remain, with the only option to dismiss them, which I believe will give the user who correctly flagged an invalid flag. This doesn't seem right.

Proposal: If a user is destroyed, any flags associated with the account should be dismissed and marked as valid.

Title: Flagging a non-answer that has obviously already been flagged
Body:
When browsing the homepage, I often come across new answers that don't qualify as answers (e.g. they are actually other questions, or just a comment). I then, of course, flag them. But in the case where there are already comments such as "This does not provide an answer [blablabla] - From review", it is obvious that some other user previously flagged it, and that it is already in the review queue.

So, in this case, should I still flag these posts as "not an answer"? Does it serve some useful purpose, like voting for these posts to be deleted (assume I have access to the low-quality review queue), or does it just somewhat add noise to the system?

Title: Moderator candidate statistics - badge count is zero in the elections stack exchange
Body:
In the Elections page for the moderator candidate statistics, the badge counts are displaying as zero.

For an example, in the recent Travel SE election site the badge counts for main and meta sites are displaying as 0 for gold/silver/bronze.

Screenshot for reference:

Title: Add ability to reply to specific comment
Body:
Sometimes someone may post more than one comment on a post. If I am referring to one of their older comments it is hard to tell which one I am responding to, without going into details in the comment ("Regarding your comment on January 21st, [...]").

It would be nice to add a chat-like reply feature, where your comment's @ mention is replaced with a link to a specific comment, while still appearing as an @ mention, but with a reply symbol in front of it. Clicking on the mention would highlight the replied-to comment.

Here is a screenshot of something similar in chat:

Body:
I'm trying add Euler Project image into my profile by specifying its URL in img form (https://projecteuler.net/profile/Andremoniy.png). But it gives me error:

Failed to upload image; the format is not supported

Of course, I can save it to disk, reformat and upload. But it is not convenient. Why isn't system able to upload this picture?

Furthermore, is any method to automatically update this picture in my profile or not?

Title: Questions got serial down-votes, revenge?
Body:
While I'm reviewing my profile, I did notice a strange behavior especially on my 0 votes questions:

As you can note here, 4 votes down on the 4 so different questions in 1 minutes, that target my 0 votes questions to be -1 fo all, which this is an annoying part here!

I don't really bother myself with this, but still, I want to understand how to prevent that or report that.

I tried to find a question similar to this, but I found nothing talking about this case exactly, (or I was searching for incorrect words).

Any explanation and how to report this? Especially that down caster seems smart guy trying to avoid the auto-detect system of stack overflow system.

Title: Allow moderators to rollback locked posts (more easily)
Body:
Locked posts really are locked to most users. To moderators, however, locked posts are substantially less locked. Moderators can edit them, post comments to them, delete comments from them, and even if need be unlock them.

There is a curious gap in moderator powers, however. Moderators cannot rollback a locked post. A not uncommon use of locking (at least on Mathematics, where I rule reside) is when a user is continually defacing their question (because they'd really rather delete it, but cannot due to answers) and you just want to hit pause on that situation.

I have just recently experienced a case where a user re-defaced their question within 20 seconds of my having rolled it back. When faced with a user who is this determined to deface their posts, a much easier workflow would be to first lock the post and then put it into a previous good state. I should now note that there are ways of doing this.

  1. As moderators can edit locked posts, just go to the source of the previous good revision, copy it, and make a good new revision.
  2. Moderators can edit revisions, and simply "editing" and saving an old revision will effectively roll it back. (This I have only recently become aware of.)

But if a moderator attempts to simply rollback a locked post in the usual manner, they are met with a popup declaring

This makes no sense to me: I'm a moderator gosh darn it!

Since there are methods for moderators to effectively rollback locked posts, wouldn't it be easier to just allow us that small additional privilege to actually rollback locked posts?

Title: Sidebar glitches on Markdown page
Body: On a page like this, after scrolling for a little while, the sidebar will suddenly fling to the bottom of the screen and remain fixed:

Title: Have the edit keyboard shortcut be equivalent to clicking on the edit link
Body:
If there's a pending edit on a post, and I have editing privileges, clicking on the edit(1) link will open up the review panel. But pressing e will do nothing. It would be nice to have the review panel open up on pressing e in this case.

Even for people without edit privs, it'd be nice to see what edits are pending (so that if I had a different edit in mind, I could check back in later). That'd probably be a different feature request, though.

Title: Saving an answer for offline viewing
Body:
I want to save a lengthy answer to a question, to read on the bus tomorrow morning - to remain productive, rather than stare at the road.

I'm too poor to afford mobile internet; is there a way I can nicely view this offline, say, by converting it to an image or pdf?

I could take 10 screen-shots of the answer, is this the best way? I use windows phone, which I don't think has an option to manually cache a page for later viewing.

Body:

All image issues seem to be loaded to imgur: https://i.sstatic.net/whatever

At this time, I'm told when I try to upload an image of what I'm seeing I get:

Failed to upload image; imgur is rejecting the request

Title: Where to ask general performance related questions about web sites/apps?

Where would be a good place to ask general performance related questions about websites and webapps?

The Stack exchange communities Stack Overflow, Server Fault, Webmasters and Web Applications would be a possibility.

(What do I mean by "general"? E.g. discussing the sitespeed.io web best practice suggestions list)

Title: Dupe text should change to reflect that a question has multiple duplicates
Body:
The current text is:

This question was marked as an exact duplicate of an existing question.

But in reality, it is an duplicate of multiple questions.

Should this copy be changed?

Title: What's going to replace the moderator newsletter when Blog Overflow is shut down?
Body:
I realize I might be jumping the gun a bit in asking this question, but I'm very curious to know what Stack Exchange is going to be replacing the moderator newsletter with, given that it's hosted on Blog Overflow.

I'll grant that it's been a long time since we've gotten a mod newsletter announcement. Still, in the past, it's been a valuable tool to alert moderators to major upcoming or present changes to moderator tools and features, such as the addition of moderator vacation notices. It seems like an invaluable tool for network-wide notifications that's going to be hard to directly replace.

The Blog Overflow announcement has this to say:

[We're] looking at something that can be directly a part of the Stack Exchange system [to replace the moderator newsletter.]

What options is Stack Exchange looking at? And/or, do you all know already what's going to replace it - if so, what is it going to be?

Title: Badge - Civic Duty - Vote 300 or more times
Body: What is Badge - Civic Duty It has simple description "Vote 300 or more times". I'm looking for detail of this badge. I can't see any effect upon down vote question/answers. Does it consider down vote also.

Title: Undo upvote if the comment is edited
Body: There should be an option to undo your comment upvote if a comment gets edited. It is likely that you upvote something else which gets useless or provides incorrect information after the edit.

Title: Allow editing tag info on iOS app
Body:
Currently, when viewing tag-info in the Stack Exchange iOS app, there doesn't seem to be an easy way to suggest edits for tag info.

Why not have an action bar like the one on question pages?

Title: "Our system has identified this post as possible spam" message shown twice
Body:
Another non-critical bug, but I've long since noticed that when you are reviewing a low-quality answer (I'm pretty sure I've noticed it on multiple stacks) which the system has identified as possible spam, a "Our system has identified this post as possible spam; please review carefully" message shows up not only over the answer but also over the question which is shown below for reference.

A picture is worth a thousand words (screenshot from a review on Ask Ubuntu):

In this particular case it was a review audit, but I'm fairly certain I've seen the same bug elsewhere - and if I haven't, it's kind of a dead give away for review audits which ought to be removed.

Title: Links with plain URLs as markdown code don't automatically display the title of the question when one link in the post doesn't have a plain URL code
Body:
I recently edited this question to change the text displayed on one of the links. The question is asking why burnination request questions often have funny titles and had a list of links to examples of questions with these kinds of titles, all links in that list used plain URL as markdown code, which automatically displayed the titles of the questions. Since one of those questions had changed title, I decided to edit it so that the link would display the old title instead, which is more relevant to the question.

This is the code of how the link was displayed first:

http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/295233/should-we-throw-corners-in-the-corner

I edited it into the following:

[Should we throw the [corners] in the corner?](http://meta.stackoverflow.com/questions/295233/should-we-throw-corners-in-the-corner)

I only edited that link and left all the other links alone, since their titles were still relevant to the question. The problem is that doing so messed up the formatting of all the other links:

As you can see, the link to which I gave a custom text was displayed fine, but all the other links lost their automatic formatting and displayed the URLs instead of the titles.

When I noticed that, I undid my edit. That didn't solve the problem, the links were still displayed as URLs. So I tried to rollback, and that didn't either solve the problem. So the only way I could solve this problem was to manually edit each link to make it display the title of the question.

Could this bug please be fixed?

Title: Linking to downloadable files as citations
Body:
We know that link-only answers aren't really appropriate, and that the links should ideally be used as citations against the text that is provided in the answer itself. But what if that link is to a downloadable file rather than a website?

I have seen a recent post where the answerer (a first-time poster) gives a summary bit of text that provides some degree of answer, but with a link to download a zip file (from their own website) that allegedly covers off more detail and reasoning.

Now, we could remove that link as spam, but then the answer text itself would not have any evidence supporting it. There's not much point asking them to summarize the content of the file, because they're more or less done that with the answer text. But I'm not sure if I'm comfortable leaving up links to download zip files from users personal webspace.

Are such links appropriate?

Title: How do I bookmark a comment for my own reading later?
Body:
Throughout the stack exchange sites, often times it happens with me that I find a particularly engaging discussion on a topic, but can't read it immediately due to lack of time or whatever.

When I later try to find that discussion, I cannot at times. It's frustrating.

I'm aware of the star symbol under questions which lets me bookmark it. But if I have to find a particular comment, I still have to scroll down a lot to find it. It's a real pain in the a**.

I'm not looking to permalink a discussion to share it somewhere else. I just want to be able to bookmark it for my own reading...later.

How can I do this? Is there a browser plugin or such that'll let me do this?

Title: Answering community wiki question
Body:
According to answer to the post What are “Community Wiki” posts?:

An answer posted to a community wiki question will also be community wiki.

What is the reason to make answer community wiki automatically in this case?

I'm not sure when exactly I last upvoted a comment, but it was likely within the last week, and possibly the last few hours.

I'm using version 1.0.89, which hasn't been updated since September of last year. Was there a server-side update that changed this? Or perhaps something has changed locally on my device (I'm definitely still logged in)?

I've noticed that the "share" links on answers and comments note that they not only include the answer ID, but the user's ID as well:

Why does Stack Exchange do this? Obviously, it is tracking it, but for what purpose? Does this affect the user?

Title: In a Tag Info, shouldn’t the “history” link being labeled “full wiki history”?
Body:
Next to the “Edit Tag Info” button, which allows to edit both excerpt and full wiki texts, there’s to links to the version histories of both texts:

A “Tag Wiki” consists of a “tag wiki excerpt” as well as a “full tag wiki”. While the rightmost history link specifically says “excerpt history”, the other is merely labeled “history”, which apparently refers to the history of all the Tag Info (or at least something more than just the full tag wiki history).

It’s not easy to come up with a distinct label text, and it’s not very important at all, but the link text should probably be ajusted to be less ambiguous (next to its specific counterpart).

Title: Blog page with out favicon
Body: I clicked the BLOG link listed in the Stack Exchange side bar. The page opened with out the favicon.

Title: Automated warning for questions about something that "does not work"
Body:
All too often on various SE sites I see questions which share a common flaw: the OP states that his contraption does not work, without any useful information about the issue. A comment asking for clarification usually appears shortly after the question is posted, after which the question is typically put on hold as unclear, unless the OP is quick enough to provide a useful description of their problem.

I wonder if it's possible to warn well-meaning users in advance, so they don't have to rush against the close votes piling up, by showing them a warning message while they're writing their question, e.g.

Note that does not work is not a useful problem statement. Please explain what behavior you have observed and what you expected to see.

This way, users who strive to write a good question will get the warning before their experience is spoiled by downvotes / close vote / sarcastic comments. Those who don't care will of course post anyway, but at least I'll spend less time dealing with them, since there will be no need to ask for clarification, wait, check again and vote to close: I'll know I can vote to close directly.

When I started writing this question I was going to suggest imposing a restriction to does not work questions, like the one we have for the word problem. By now, I don't think it's a good idea anymore. A warning will improve the experience for well-meaning users (which is the most important part) without really restricting anyone.

Title: Is there a guideline for downvoting?
Body:
I'm just curious if there exists an actual guideline for when to use downvotes. Are they used solely for questions worded poorly or with little/no research? Are they used when you don't understand the question?

I mean, I know people will use them however they want, but I'm just curious if some sort of "best use policy" was ever covered?

Title: Deleting or Closing an Answered Question if Off Topic
Body:
I have a question elsewhere which has been voted down, and has 2 votes to close it.

I think anonymous down votes are supremely unhelpful, and that topic has been discussed already. However, I accept that the question can be regarded as off topic, and so it would be appropriate to close or delete it.

I don’t think I am able to close the question, but I can delete it. However, I get the warning about being blocked from asking. The problem is that while it’s live, it runs the risk of more (anonymous) down votes.

The question is: if I agree that the question is off-topic, what is the most suitable action to take?

Title: What do the numbers to the left and right of my tags mean?
Body:
I looked at my tags section and saw two numbers without an explanation.

I'm guessing one of these is tag score, and that is what I'm looking for to see my progress towards a tag badge.

Is there an explanation for what the numbers mean?

Title: Elections inbox item is empty in network profile global inbox
Body:
I got an inbox message about the elections on Super User yesterday, all good.

However, when checking now my global inbox on stackexchange.com network profile, it's empty:

The inbox item on the top bar is fine:

The empty item also got no link to the elections. Can this please be fixed?

Title: Should I upvote complimentary comments on my answer?
Body:
I'm a frequent reader/lurker but an infrequent contributer on several SE sites. Occasionally I craft an answer to a question which is better-received than usual, and one or two kind users add a comment which is basically a compliment - "I especially liked the bit about X" or "the way you explained Y".

Should I upvote such comments? I like to acknowledge that I appreciate such positive feedback, but at the same time it feels like blowing my own trumpet: "I agree with your opinion that my post is great".

What is the primary implication of upvoting a positive comment in this way - agreement, or acknowledgement?

Title: Is it possible to collect data from SE users to understand their usage of the site?
Body:
I wonder if SE supports conducting research by allowing the collection of some data from its users. For example, I want to investigate what characteristics of users determine their behaviors in SE (e.g., type of questions they ask, their badges, etc.).

I wonder what would be a reasonable approach to conduct such research?

Title: Horizontal scroll bar appears in Google Chrome when not needed (line with 93 characters with default zoom)
Body:
The horizontal scroll bar appears in Google Chrome (with default zoom) when a line 93 has characters, which isn't needed. Example:

model_saver.save(sess, os.path.join(model_folder, 'model_{0:05d}.ckpt'.format(epoch_number)))

Rendering:

It works fine with firefox:

Title: "Show console" in "JavaScript/HTML/CSS snippet"
Body:
The advanced options in "JavaScript/HTML/CSS snippet" all have help icons except "Show console", so:

  1. Could you add a help icon there too?
  2. Can you describe here exactly what it does?

Title: Community wiki card - text looks wrong
Body:
Sometimes a community wiki post has a percentage attached to it. It means that a certain percentage of the post was written by a specific user, as described in this answer.

The problem is, the resulting text looks confusing. For example (this example was taken from here):

community wiki
193 revs, 13 users 36%
JasonMArcher

It seems that there is always a linebreak between the percentage and the user's name, which makes it unclear what the percentage really means.

The following designs look better:

community wiki
193 revs, 13 users
36% JasonMArcher

community wiki
193 revs, 13 users
36% by JasonMArcher

They may be implemented by adding a non-breaking space, as suggested here, or a forced linebreak before the percentage.

Title: Privilege icon is missing if viewing the achievements dialog from stackexchange.com
Body:
When viewing the achievements dialog from any site other than stackexchange.com the privilege icon is displaying.

But when I viewing the achievements dialog from stackexchange.com the privilege icon is not displaying.

This question is not the duplicate of this question, since the existing question is mention about the mobile view/mobile app. The current post is about the issue with the stackexchange.com in the desktop view alone.

Title: Should users be reported for deleted comments?
Body:
If a user leaves a rude or offensive comment and then deletes it, should there be a way flag or report the message?

For instance, let's say that a user leaves an offensive comment. Someone sees that comment and goes to report it to a moderator. But before they can, the user deletes their own post.

What's the proper response in this scenario? It could be argued that, since the comment was removed, there's no longer a reason to make a report. On the other hand, the user never gets reported for posting offensive content.

Title: Any further discussion on not using "guest" email address gravatars?
Body:
This question (Anonymous questions and Avatars) was asked two years ago. Today I experienced what the OP did - posted as "guest" on a SE, used my real email address which SE assured me would never be seen, and to my surprise my personal gravatar was used as the image which to me is as good as posting my email address.

In the original question, it's stated by @oded that the site shouldn't do that and they'd look into it. Then it's stated in another answer by @shog9 that they'd give a workflow change some consideration.

I don't want to discuss whether or not using my real address to post as a guest was a good idea (obviously it wasn't). I just want to know if either of the two solutions that were going to be looked into were. And if so, why they were both rejected.

Title: Meta sites infinite redirect loop
Body:
Since yesterday, meta.mathematica.stackexchange.com redirects to mathematica.meta.stackexchange.com. At the same time, my browser (Chrome) goes into a redirect loop, so I cannot visit the site.

If I try to visit the site in incognito mode, then all is fine, so I thought that (as the message suggests) I just need to clear some cookies. But after clearing all cookies with "stackexchange" in the name, it still doesn't work.

Short of deleting all cookies (which I really do not want to do), how can I fix this?

Title: Autobiographer badge is cross-site, but Informed badge is site-specific?
Body: This question has been bugging me ever since the few minutes I spent joining several Stack Exchange sub-sites whose subjects fell within my interests and thus I expect to be active in within the foreseeable future (19 of them, to be exact): How come the Authobiographer badge is auto-unlocked across all SE sites (i.e. you only need to complete one "About Me" section), but the Informed badge has to be unlocked separately for each site despite the Tour page being virtually identical in each case? Not that I'm complaining, but is there an actual point behind this redundancy?

Title: Disable bounty-related notifications, if there is no answer to award bounty
Body:
My bounty failed. It was aimed to attract at least one answer, but no answer was actually given. Do I still need to see these -- a bit annoying -- reminders that my bounty is about expire within... 3 days... 1 day etc.? Can these be disabled in this situation.

I mean... what should I actually do with these reminders or what is their purpose -- what should they remind me? Neither I can't award bounty to any answer manually nor it can be awarded automatically, because... there are no answers.

Title: Some questions regarding SE network statistics on about page
Body:
About us of both SE and SO shows "2015 Stack Exchange Network Statistics" with same figures.

  • I think both can show their statistics i.e "SO statistics on SO about page" and "SE statistics on SE about page".

  • Why do statistics show only "Registered Stack Overflow users" (not SE in-spite of being SE statistics)? We can mention SO specific figure in brackets like have been doing for "Pageviews" figure.

  • When are we going to update it to "2016 Stack Exchange Network Statistics"?

Thanks.

Title: How do you retrieve API site names from /associated?
Body:
The /associated API call returns an array of network_user objects, each of which looks like this:

{
  "badge_counts": {
    "bronze": 1,
    "silver": 2,
    "gold": 3
  },
  "question_count": 25,
  "answer_count": 50,
  "last_access_date": 1489836385,
  "creation_date": 1489793185,
  "account_id": 1,
  "reputation": 9001,
  "user_id": 1,
  "site_url": "http://example.stackexchange.com/",
  "site_name": "Example Site"
}

The only fields there that identify the site are site_url and site_name.

All of the rest of the per-site API calls take a site query parameter, whose value is some string that does not appear to be included in the above results. For example stackoverflow, russian, or woodworking.

So my question is: Given a network_user, how do I determine what the corresponding site query parameter value is for that site?

For example, an application that queries for associated accounts, then performs an operation on one of those sites. This seems like a relatively straightforward use case, but I am not sure how to make it work.

Title: Mixed content on stackexchange.com
Body:
When I open https://stackexchange.com/, the padlock icon in my Firefox has a yellow warning triangle icon, clicking on it, the message says:

Connection is Not Secure

Parts of this page are not secure (such as images).

F12 console contains many messages like (all of them about gravatar.com URLs):

Loading mixed (insecure) display content “http://www.gravatar.com/avatar/195aa8870c17b0e8ad0c623af6f6466c?s=16&d=identicon&r=PG&s=30” on a secure page

Since the HTTPs version of that URL seems to work fine, I think they should be changed.

Title: When does Community ♦ cast votes?
Body:
I recently noticed on Ask Ubuntu that Community ♦ casts upvotes and downvotes. I read in this post that Community can cast downvotes in some cases, but I haven't found any information on upvotes. Here's a screenshot from Community's profile on AU:

I checked on a few other sites; here is mechanics.stackexchange's Community profile:

And Stack Overflows:

And last but not least, IoT beta:

So my question is, under what situations can Community vote on posts?

Title: Automatic http to https links replacement job causing wrong "last modified by" information
Body:
I just noticed this on MSE homepage:

Curious, I clicked the link, which led to this answer. Which was NOT modified by Community:

Time stamp match, but not the user doing the action.

Digging a bit further, turns out it's because of automatic non-bumping process that replace http:// links with https:// links all around the site, e.g. on the question itself. While indeed not bumping on its own, when something else bumped the question to the front page, the last modified by showing Community.

Can this please be fixed? Expect to see the actual last modifier in those cases.

Title: What is use of background colour in question lists?
Body:
For filtered question lists, if seems that new questions have background colour applied until I have actually seen them in the list. On successive viewing, it is no longer present.

However for Arduino lists of all questions, I can find no rhyme or reason to the use of such. When there is background colour, I can see the question in the list or even open it, but there is no change following this. What am I missing here? Surely it is intended to impart some piece of information. I had read many FAQs and questions, but can find no reference to such behaviour.

Title: Adding tag description
Body:
I have just created a new tag. However, I'm not allowed to edit the tag description, it will need to be peer reviewed.

If I have the permission to create a tag, wouldn't it make sense to also have permission to create the tag's description?

This way, there will be less tags without description and less reviewing for moderators.

Title: More Question Filtering options
Body:
I realize that this may be a big request, but...

I think that instead of tabs on the recent question activity pages, or more likely as a new tab, adding a more advanced filtering option.

For instance, being allowed to exclude tags, filter by accepted answers or not, and, most importantly, being able to combine multiple filters!

E.g.: Filtering posts with tag Javascript without tags Jquery and AngularJS with no accepted answers and a score >= 0.

I feel like this is a biggish change that, if implemented as a new tab, wouldn't be that hard to implement, but would be very useful.

Title: Please allow us to disable oneboxing in chat
Body:
I'd like to propose a setting for chatrooms that prevents link-only messages from being transformed to oneboxes.

Oneboxes have a purpose, and generally speaking they're - sort of - nice to have in chatrooms. Some chatrooms however do not "allow" oneboxes, as they clutter up the transcript. Personally I do not mind oneboxes in "fun" chatrooms (where having fun is literally all that counts), but they can be very obnoxious in rooms where discussions take place.

Problems that I see with oneboxes:

  • potentially content that I don't want to see, from links I wouldn't open (i.e. images)
  • disruptive when it comes to conversations
  • oneboxes can be obnoxiously big depending on the source

Related:

  • Overrides/preferences for chat oneboxing

  • Can we make oneboxing optional on mobile chat?

  • Make chat oneboxing smaller and less obnoxious - click to enlarge instead

Title: What can a mod do about a comment posted as an answer?
Body:
In this revision of the Guidelines for reviewing low-quality posts, we can read under the sub section Comments posted as an answer

If the answer would actually be a constructive comment, consider flagging it for moderator attention.

What would a mod do that a non-mod can't do? Can they transform an answer into a comment?

Title: What's up with "Edit"
Body: When someone edits a posting, can they simply edit it? Why do they have to mark it with "Edit:". Authors of books don't do this. Postings would read a lot smoother and look more permanent, if they didn't include "Edit:" all over the place. If I want to see the edit history, it is available.

I'm not sure how it happened but my @gmail email is listed under aliases when it did not used to be (its what I wanted but I'm not sure how it happened as I had not added it yet), and when I try to login with it, I am told that I do not have the right password. When I recover my password it defaults to my @university email address and I still cannot login with my gmail email.

When I reset my password, this is the email I got (at my gmail account as I have set that as the "contact" email):

For example if creating a query that has some per-site stuff built-in, like privilege thresholds, or e.g. generating URLs from IDs with the correct domain name, I'd like to be able to determine the site so I can code possibilities into the query itself.

Title: Save function requested
Body: Some times I come accross an answer that is super good, and I know I will need to look at this again.. I usually upvote such questions/answers.. but, some times it is hard to find them again (unless I do something as oldfashion as bookmark it), so I would like to "save" it... for myself.. so that later I can look at my own "saved" answers, and this is a much smaller subset of all the answers out there (think reddit save funtion).

Title: What's the rationale behind not parsing HTML entities in chat?
Body:
It seems status-bydesign that HTML entities are not parsed in chat. What's the rationale for this?

In my humble opinion, HTML entities can be very useful. I would be able to freely type "—" with — and "–" with – instead of looking up their Unicode, instead of the really short and annoying hyphen. Heck, the minus sign is itself larger than a hyphen.

So, what is the rationale behind not allowing HTML entities? If it's potential for abuse, wouldn't it be better to disallow posting a message containing nothing but  1? Or is there some other reason these aren't parsed?

1: Even so, people can easily post empty messages, so this is not a great counter.

Title: More emphasis on scope for new users
Body:
I've noticed that many new users post questions that fall out of the scope of a particular site and get closed. Often these are very common (such as idea generation on Worldbuilding SE or homework problems on a science SE site). These get closed with only a two-line explanation that doesn't adequately explain what the scope is and why it is needed and why the particular question doesn't lie in scope.

Therefore I think there should be a clear page that explains the concept of scope and also a list of site specific examples of commonly received types of questions from new users that actually fall out of scope. These examples can be crafted using hypothetical users. Examples do help teach scope properly. And it is easier to convince someone that their question is similar to an example that is declared off-scope rather than an abstract explanation like 'idea generation not allowed'.

P.S. This is perhaps even more important than explaining how reputation works, which can be explained to users who actually plan to stay longer than a couple of questions.

Title: How to ask a question when you want to answer yourself?
Body:
I have seen a few times that this website encourages asking questions for which you already have an answer and to post this answer also. I did exactly this on stack overflow providing the code for a certain function.

I must admit that my question was not perfect as "I was not showing what I had tried". Obviously what I had tried was already the solution to the problem, so I posted it only in the answer itself.

Some people have downvoted the question probably because of not being the kind of question of somebody who has really made an effort to find a solution by himself. Therefore my prize for trying to share my code is losing reputation and I feel that discouraging.

Could you point me towards any successful example of somebody answering his own question to see how to do it?
Could you point me out what is so awful about mine? Calculate the module of a vector, or square root of a number, in VHDL

Finally, what do you think about somehow locking the voting of the question in the situation in which the user is also answering by himself? I mean that in order to downvote such question the voter is forced to notice that the asker has answered by himself, not trying to get an advantage out of other users in exchange for nothing.

Title: Error message if deleting a comment fails is misleading
Body:
I get a "An error occurred during voting" error message in a red popup when deleting a comment fails. But that message is misleading as I wasn't voting the comment but deleting it. It should be "An error occurred during deleting".

Steps to reproduce:

  1. Post a comment, say, 'Blah blah bladdeddy blah!'
  2. Disconnect your device from the internet
  3. Press the delete button X next to the comment
  4. You get "An error occurred during voting" which is misleading

Title: How to read up on what's on topic in-app?
Body:
When I join a new site I don't want my first question to be closed as off-topic. On the web I can navigate the help labyrinth to arrive at an answer, but I can't find that info in-app, nor a link to the help.

I think it's natural to have this close at hand when writing one's first question on a new site.

Unless it's already in here somewhere, I'd like to request it

Title: Duplicate list edits should be shown on the question itself
Body:
Editing the list of duplicates on a question bumps said question and appears as a revision in the questions revision history, there is no indication on the question page itself though.

So this is what you see on the homepage, with the user and timestamp of the edit:

This is what you see in the revision history:

On the question itself... nothing:

Seeing a post was edited on the homepage then opening it to see nothing has changed is pretty confusing. This is, as far as I know (?), now the only thing that will bump a question with no indication on the question itself (community bumps used to; they now have a notice).

Title: Notify close voters when a question receives three reopen votes
Body:
On sites with a lot of users it can be hard for a question which was closed to be reopened because the question gets pushed away and hidden from a lot of the common places people find questions.

On smaller sites, there aren't many people around to cast reopen votes.

I close a lot of questions, and don't want to be notified about every little thing that happens (edits, comments etc).

However, I would be happy to be told a question which I closed is over halfway open again because this is not a trivial hurdle, and I'm likely to want to take a look.

Title: User should be able to see username email in iOS app
Body: I want to login on web application with the same credentials which I have with ios app. But I have forgotten the username and email. Is there any way to use the same credentials in web app?

Title: My Google-based connection ID not usable, Atlassian Crowd problem
Body:
So, I have a Stack Exchange account. When I first created it a couple of years back, I used my "Google" credentials. Fine. Then late last year I began work with a company which uses Atlassian Crowd to manage IDs and logins, and at some point my Stack Exchange account must have become associated with my id at that company. Now my Stack Exchange account is inaccessible.

But it does exist.

Is there some way to reconnect to my Stack Exchange id?

Title: Duplicate question from same user, neither one has answers
Body: What should I do if I see that a user has posted the exact same problem multiple times? Neither of the questions have answers, so I can't flag the latter one as a duplicate of the first one. Is it okay if I flag it for moderator attention?

Title: Generally horrible questions
Body:
I think we need a close reason for generally bad questions that are hard to find a close reason for. Ones that are usually getting shoehorned into "Too Broad" or "Unclear What You're Asking". Something like:

This question shows a complete lack of understanding of the general concepts, and as such is unlikely to be answerable in its current form. A tutorial is likely in order.

and/or

This answer is asking for code or homework help, and shows no effort at solving the problem. It is unlikely to be able to be edited to get better.

If anyone knows what the consensus is on what to do with these questions when they come up, please enlighten me.

TL;DR: It's too hard to choose an accurate close reason for homework / give me code / complete misunderstanding of the language/concepts as a whole questions.

Title: Flag dialogue popup is stacked behind realtime-post-deleted-notification banners
Body:
There is a little bug that becomes visible when a page contains realtime-post-deleted-notification banners (that's the CSS classname of these red banners appearing on answers which just got deleted, see screenshot below) and you try to open the flag dialogue above them:

Obviously, the dialogue appears below the banners, which it clearly should not do. It also has no input focus, trying to interact with the dialogue fails and either closes it (clicking outside of the red banners) or reloads the page (clicking on the red banners).

The cause for this is simply the z-index ordering in the site's CSS. Relevant CSS snippets:

.realtime-post-deleted-notification {
    position: absolute;
    text-align: center;
    z-index: 100;
}

.popup {
    display: none;
    padding: 15px;
    position: absolute;
    z-index: 10;
}

So the fix for this minor bug would probably be to raise the z-index of the popup class to something greater than 100.

Title: Let's see the Top Network Askers better

Quick check showed it's because SE is requesting the 16x16 thumbnail, while having 30x30 size of the image itself, which cause the image to stretch.

Changing to 32x32 will make it much better:

Title: Adding migration site when closing a question

For instance, I wanted to close a question on Mathematics.SE and migrate it to Cryptography.SE, but the only options provided were MathOverflow, Physics, etc.

Title: Remove notification that triggers upon final bounty expiration
Body:
Bounties automatically trigger four notifications, one when three days of advertising remain, one when only one is left, a third when the grace period begins as the last chance to manually award the bounty, and a final one when there is nothing anyone can do about the bounty except maybe flag for bounty fraud.

Why do we even have that one? It's easily as negative as, say being downvoted, which we don't like to highlight in the topbar, and far less actionable. It's just a handy way to say "Hey, you know that 50/100/500 rep you spent a week and change ago? Well, not only are you certainly not getting it back, but it was utterly wasted and useless and achieved absolutely none of your goals, and there's not a thing you can do about it. Good going. Aren't you glad you decided to put up the bounty?"

To be completely honest, I'd prefer if the rest of the system's philosophy toward notifications was changed to match this, but if not, at least fix this single most egregious example of this sort of downer notification!

Title: New navigation UI issue
Body:
Browser - Chrome

Screen resolution - 1366 x 768

The down arrow key position is not good in my browser view. I have marked with red color.

Title: Zero value in relative dates in search
Body:
Using SE search engine you can find posts active on relative dates. E.g.:

  • posts active yesterday: lastactive:1d
  • posts active from yesterday to most recent: lastactive:1d..

But search criteria like lastactive:1d..0d is not recognized.

My request is to recognize relative dates with zero at the end (Nd..0d) same as Nd...

More over for search posts active on today you could use lastactive:0d. Currently to search for today posts you need to specify absolute date only.

Title: Is it a good idea to edit the spam away instead of waiting for enough flags to be raised?
Body:
The aim of this question is to understand what the system prefers.

On Aviation it often happens that spam messages end up in the LQ queue and thus end up being "reccommended for deletion" but not flagged as spam. They end up deleted, but not recognized as spam from the system.

As a consequence, some users have started to edit away the spammy posts while they are in the queue.

Is this a good idea? I.e., does the spam prevention system like this? Or should we somehow prod more users into flagging the posts instead?

Title: Voting buttons for locked posts
Body:
I noticed that voting for locked question is not possible:

For posts that have historical lock voting button are not even visible:

What is the reason to display voting buttons for regular locked posts if voting is not possible at all, why no to hide it as done for historical locked posts?

Title: What would happen if someone who is suspended created a new account and tries to have it merged it later?
Body:
Let's say someone:

  1. has his Stack Exchange account suspended for a year;
  2. then created a new account;
  3. tries to merge it with his previous account after the suspension is over.

What would happen then since it's theoretically not allowed as it defeats the purpose of the suspension.

However, sometimes there is a question and someone edited it, I call up the edit and approve it. But then it needs three more approval votes before the edit becomes visible. Seems a contradiction?

Title: Should I do anything about a user posting their mobile number on their About Me?
Body:
I recently visited a user's profile page and noticed that they have posted their mobile number on the "About Me" section. In my opinion, this isn't the kind of personal information that should be shared and the user should be encouraged to remove it.

Does this even need bringing to anybody's attention? Should the user be encouraged to remove it? While it is personal information, the user has volunteered the information and should potentially be allowed to do so.

If this should be actioned, how, and to whom should I report this?

Title: Protected questions and overall SO network reputation
Body:
I recently wanted to give an answer on an SO platform, but instead had to write a comment.

The weird thing is, that I think the comment would have been a decent answer, which in turn could bump me well above the threshold to answer protected questions.

I also have the 100 rep bonus, and 1900 reputation or more overall on the SO network.

I think it would be cool if a user with enough reputation say 1000 or 1500 overall on the SO network (real reputation not with the bonus counted), could still answer protected questions.

The reason is that I think it's unlikely that someone with a lot of reputation would write a bad answer on another SO platform.

I don't know if it can be implemented though and what each SO platform has access to.

I mean you can still give the information in a comment, or ask someone in chat to post it for you, but you will forfeit the potential gain of reputation, which then would allow you to answer future protected questions (which are the ones you are most likely to see, because you're likely not actively search on that particular network, but instead only see the hot networks)

Ofcourse you could argue that this is design, but somehow I think that this could prevent a few people which could post gem answers for specific situation/contexts they are familiar with, but are simply not active on that network.

Title: Why do some sites redirect to HTTPS but not others?
Body: More specifically, http://*meta.stackexchange.com/ redirects to https://*meta.stackexchange.com, but http://*stackexchange.com/ does not redirect to https://*stackexchange.com. It is the same with the stackoverflow.com domain. Why is this the case?

Body: I can't connect to http://elections.stackexchange.com or https://elections.stackexchange.com — the initial connection times out every time. I check this every week, and it worked fine last time, so it must be something pretty recent. (Further HTTPS deployment?)

Title: Android App saying I have not joined a community, even though I have
Body:
So I have been using the mobile app for a while now, with no errors at all. Today I opened the application up as usual and started browsing the Ask Different (Apple) community. When I tried to downvote/upvote/comment, it said

You are not part of this community, would you like to join it?

I clicked yes, because it wouldn't let me do anything else. Even after clicking yes, it would not let me upvote, and soon crashed.

When I reopened the app, the same thing occurred. I decided to logout, and log back in, but had no success. Finally, I decided to reinstall the app, but once again had no luck.

I am on the Latest Android (7.1.2) and am on a Google Pixel.

Not sure if it's my issue, because the new software updates rolled out today, or if it is a general bug.

Title: Shortcut for code formatting in comments on mobile
Body:
It's commonly known that you can use code formatting by surrounding your code with backticks: `enter code here`.

Unfortunately, the ` character is fairly well hidden on the default iOS keyboard, making it inconvenient at best, or impossible to find at worst.

This isn't an issue when writing questions or answers, since there's a convenient "insert code button", but unfortunately there's no such button when writing comments.

There should be an alternative way of enclosing code on mobile devices, such as a code formatting button when writing comments.

Title: Reputation from Documentation links shown differently in iOS app
Body:
iOS 10.3, App version 1.6.4

In the feed view "Earlier Today" section, rep gained from links to Documentation topics I've edited appear as links to the questions/answers where the topic is referenced.

I don't recall ever having seen this before, and it led to some head-scratching since I'm not in any way associated with those questions or any of their answers. It took a few minutes to figure out why I was getting the rep.

In the Achievements page and in the web UI, these links don't appear and the the rep is shown as just "Arrays"

I suppose it could be useful to see the question/answer where the Doc topic is linked.

Is this working as intended? Should it work this way or just mirror the Achievements view.

[IMHO it's excessive that every link to a Doc topic that I somehow touched at some point in distant memory gives me rep, but that's for another discussion.]

Title: Late Answers review audits are too hard
Body:
I have been always reviewing the "Late Answers" queue with fear. I always click out the question to see if the answer is deleted (to determine if it's an audit, and to checkout other answers).

Late Answers audits are too hard for the following reason:

  • The audits are mainly picked from "Close Vote" queue. This means that those audits don't reflect the characteristics of "Late Answer". Such as:

    • Duplicating current answer (can only be checked by viewing all answers)
    • Low quality answer

    These are hard to flag:

    Any post that attempts to answer the question, however badly is still an answer. You can downvote such posts to signal that the answer is a bad answer, but it is still an answer. When to flag an answer as "not an answer"?

  • The guidelines are unclear. One thing that I think it needs improvement is the treatment of link-only answers. They're often taken from Low Quality Posts queue, and at there an appropriate reason for deletion exists. However, at LA queue the correct choice is flagging as "low quality post". Low quality posts enters Triage today, and the purpose of flag is less clear than others.

Title: Inbox count wrong a lot more often than it used to be
Body:
In the past couple of weeks, I've found that my unread count (the red number) on my inbox is wrong (too high) most of the time if it's showing a number at all. This is new behavior.

Throughout the day, I'll regularly see it at [2] but click it and see that I only have one new notification; the other is one I've already cleared from the inbox previously. Or I'll see it at [5] and click to find there are really only two since I last cleared it.

Prior to a couple of weeks ago, this might happen very rarely, but now it's an every-day, more-than-once-a-day occurrence.

I'm primarily active on Stack Overflow.

Some change with unintended consequences?

Title: Ad Blocker Causing Gap
Body:
Apparently, my ad blocker was blocking certain banner ads above the body of questions.

Some examples:

I suggest that the HTML elements should be formatted in a way that automatically aligns everything to the top of that section, so when that image is removed, everything automatically moves up.

An alternative would be to put an image that says something like "Please disable your ad blocker", or anything that makes the page not seem like having a weird gap, positioned directly underneath the ad.

I know I should disable my ad blocker on SE sites (never noticed it was on before this), but that's beside the point here, since I would imagine some other users having an ad blocker on SE sites anyways.

Title: Being logged out of Area 51

Title: Edit link for Favorite Tags is not accessible
Body:
The Favorite Tags widget which appears on the right sidebar of every Stack Exchange community's homepage is not keyboard accessible because the "Edit" link does not contain a href attribute. The HTML appears as:

<h4 id="h-interesting-tags">Favorite Tags</h4>
<a id="edit-interesting">edit</a>

In terms of WCAG, this is a level A failure of 2.1.1 Keyboard. The obvious fix is to add the required href, but given its purpose as a UI control, it probably makes more semantic sense as a button.

Title: Spurious “This post has been edited” notice when improving a suggested edit
Body:
In the last weeks, the following happened to me a few times:

  1. In the suggested edits queue, I choose to improve an edit.
  2. I edit the post and submit the improved edit.

  3. I receive a notice:

    This post has been edited 2 times since you began. Your edit can only be saved if it is more thorough than the currently saved edit.

    However, there were only two recent edits to the post: the edit which I approved and my improvement to this edit.

I see no reason why this should be the intended behaviour and thus consider it a bug. As I cannot remember this happening before, I assume that it’s due to some recent change.

Title: User was removed - Why does it affect me?
Body: Why does someone else breaking the rules and being removed cause me to lose reputation for votes they had cast on my questions or answers?

Title: Flag plagiarism on OP-deleted post?
Body:
Periodically (including just now) I'll come across plagiarism where the post has been downvoted, commented on calling out the plagiarism, and subsequently deleted by the OP. (In this case — shudder — copying and pasting the HTML from a w3schools reference page into an answer. As a code block. Yikes.)

Presumably at least one of the people downvoting and/or commenting has flagged the post with a mod flag with the word "plagiarism" in it, triggering the special handling of those in the mod queue. But I don't know that, of course; we mere mortals can't see flags on posts.

Is it useful in terms of dealing with repeat plagiarists for me to flag the post even though it's been self-deleted? (This does not apply, of course, to posts deleted by a mod or the community, only ones the plagiarist deletes themselves, realizing they've been caught.)

Title: What causes a flag to be "aged away"?
Body:
In my flagged post history, I noticed a section for "aged away" flags.

What exactly are "aged away" flags? Does it just mean the flag was inactive for a while? If so, how long does a flag need to be inactive for it to age away?

Title: How does reputation reversal in special cases work?
Body:
Recently I lost a few reputation due to "User Deleted", which made me wonder about reputation reversal:

  1. If someone answered my question and I get 2 rep by accepting it, then the answerer deleted his profile, will I lose 2?
  2. If I am new to a community with only 1 rep (new user). I get a down vote without losing 2 before getting another up vote. Will I have 9 rep or 11 rep?
  3. If I have 11 rep from Question 2, then the down vote gets reverted, will I gain an extra 2 or will it remain the same?
  4. Even worse, if I am new with 1 rep. I get a up vote then a down vote and I have 9. The up vote gets retracted before the down retracts. Do I have 1 or 3?

Title: Session at Data.SE expires very quickly
Body:
Subj. The expiration time is about 1 hour or so. This is very inconvenient:

  • If I leave a query open, after some time it becomes inoperative - impossible to execute and the editor glitches
  • I have to login every time - which I don't have to at other SE sites

Title: Badge proposal: posts that are linked to often
Body:
It occurred to me that incoming links to posts may be a solid quality and/or relevance criterion. Hence, I propose a (set of) badge(s) should be added to highlight posts that are linked to more often than usual.

Similar to other badges, there can be three levels with progressively larger numbers, creating sets of bronze, silver and gold.

There are different types of links to consider:

  • Linked from a duplicate (applies only to questions).
  • Linked from a post on the same SE site.
  • Linked from a comment on the same SE site.
  • Linked from a post on any SE site.
  • Linked from a comment on any SE site.
  • Linked anywhere on the internet.

The the last is easy to game and already represented by the Announcer/Booster/Publicist trio, I think we can savely disregard it.

As for the others, I think one can reasonably draw the line at any point, or even create different badges. A question with many duplicates may have very different qualities from one that is mentioned in many different contexts.

Even though I'm more interested in the principle, here are some concrete proposals (don't give me crap for the names, and the numbers certainly require tuning):

  • Foresight/Prescience/Oracle: question has 5/50/200 duplicates
  • Handout/Article/Textbook: post linked from 20/100/500 posts on the same site
  • Connective/Interdisciplinary/Fundamental: post linked from 2/5/10 different SE sites

Possible reason against: There are already badges for "good" posts. -- Why, yes, several in fact: there are badges for views, votes, and favorites. None of these capture how relevant a post is to other posts, and can one more hurt?

Title: How can I have additional favorite tags suggested?
Body:
I like using the favorite tags feature on Travel.SE, but I suspect there's some tags that I like but I haven't added yet. For example, as of today, I frequently ask about "local-customs", but don't have it as a favorite tag, and likewise for "hot-springs" and "kansai" (a region in Japan, which I do have as a favorite tag).

Approaches I can think of, and why there's problems with them:

  • If I see an interesting question, and it isn't highlighted as having a favorite tag, and it has a tag that's interesting to me, add it as a favorite tag: one problem is that I partially use the highlighting of questions to find questions that are interesting to me, rather than looking at all of the questions. There's a lot of visa questions on there which I find boring.
  • Look at my tags page: there's no indication of which tags have already been categorized as favorite or not. So for each tag on that page, I have to then scan my existing favorite tags to see if it's included. Also, some of the tags are just based on a single answer that got a lot of reputation, such as "i94" having this answer.
  • Look at questions I've asked, and see which ones aren't highlighted: there's no highlighting of a list of questions I've asked (or here)

Title: Where to ask Pandoc questions?
Body:
Where should I ask a question about Pandoc that isn't TeX-/LaTeX-specific?

Examples:

  • Can I specify command line options in a Pandoc Markdown document?

    Sometimes, a *.md file requires (due to its content) a certain set of command line options regardless of the desired output or of other, more optional command line options. E.g. when the document contains pandoc-fignos-style figure markup, --filter pandoc-fignos will always be required when wanting meaningful non-intermediate output.

    Instead of having to remember which of my Pandoc documents requires what options, can I declare arbitrary command line options within the file itself, e.g. inside the YAML metadata? Or is there a corresponding metadatafield for each and every option that I could set instead. (If the latter, how can I find out about those field, e.g., what would be the corresponding field to --filter?)

    Tags

    pandoc pandoc-markdown pandoc-yaml-metadata cli

  • Can I specify multiple bibliography (BibTeX) files in Pandoc Metadata?

    Often, journal websites and other sources offer downloadable *.bib files for referring to individual articles. If I use these, I like to keep them as they are instead of merging them into a single file. On the command line, several files can be specified by passing the --bibliography option multiple times. Can I also list multiple files in the YAML metadata inside the document itself?

    Tags

    pandoc pandoc-markdown pandoc-yaml-metadata pandoc-citeproc

(The latter question isn't LaTeX specific AFAIK, as pandoc-citeproc will process references and *.bib files even for inputs/outputs that don't to through LaTeX for processing.)

Title: Allow improving suggested edits on the mobile website
Body:
On the normal website, once you have submitted a suggested edit, you can just click [edit] again to improve it. This does not seem to be possible on the mobile version of the website. Especially given that there's no 'preview' option on mobile, it sometimes happens that the formatting can be improved, like here (expletive has been grayed out):

It shouldn't be hard to show an [edit] link between the [share] and [flag] links, like the normal site.

Title: How many times can a post go through each review queue?
Body:
I'm aware of what can cause a post to exit a review queue. This question is about what can cause a post to return to a queue that it's already been through.

I know that a post only goes through the First Posts or Late Answers queue once; reviewing those more than once would be kind of silly. And I know that any given suggested edit goes through the Suggested Edits queue only once, though of course subsequent edit proposals can send the same post there again. What about the other three queues?

It sounds like a question can go through the Close queue more than once if the first votes expire and then somebody votes to close again. Is that always the case? Is there a limit, or could a long-running close/reopen war send a question to the queue every time? Do the same rules apply to the Reopen queue and the Close queue?

If a post exits the Low Quality queue, do subsequent NAA or VLQ flags send it back there? I think I was told, as a moderator, that they don't and so I should handle those flags, but I can't find documentation now.

Title: Let's have one set of terminology for tag synonyms, please?
Body:
On the list of tag synonyms page, the terms "Master" and "Synonym" are used.

This is clear. The "Master" tag is the tag that actually is used on the site and the "Synonym" is the tag that gets changed.

But, on the creation page, the wording is less clear:

Here, we have "Source" and "Target". I'm sure that if someone explained which is which to me, I'd understand it but it isn't instantly clear and so I'm requesting that we use the same wording on this page as on the synonym page.

Even if it were clear, why are we using two different terms for each? This makes little sense.

Title: Has any [status-deferred] issue ever been completed?
Body:
While browsing questions on Meta SE, I found the following comment by Shadow Wizard.

I'm here for ~5 years, never seen even a single status-deferred becoming status-completed. By all means, it's just a different wording for status-rejected.

Is this true? Has an issue tagged status-deferred ever been recategorized as status-completed?

Title: Why isn't my question record positive?
Body:
According to that info box, the only thing I don't a positive question record. However, the math says I should. According to my profile:

  • I have asked 8 questions
  • Of those, 3 are closed
  • 0 have been deleted
  • 0 have a negative score

According to the formula, I have a question record score of:

(8 - 0 - 3 - 0)/8 = 0.625

That's well above the 0.5 threshold. So why don't I have a positive question record (and therefore the Curious badge)?

Title: Way to view edit history on app
Body: I was looking for a way to see what was edited in one of my questions on the Android app, but there doesn't seem to be a way of viewing the edit history. Is there a way to fo this and if not can we add it in?

Title: Where should I post a question about school exchanges?
Body:
I have a question about a school exchange and was wondering on what site I should post it. The question is called:

What should I do if my exchange partner follows a religious etiquette and I don't?

Does anyone know where I should post this?

Title: Strange tag-related error message on visiting a per-site meta
Body:
I visited Beer, Wine, and Spirits Meta, from the supercollider, and got this cryptic error instead of a list of questions:

Say what? I wasn't searching tags, as you can see from the URL.

This persisted through several refreshes over a few minutes, but as I finished composing this question the site returned to normal behavior. So the site isn't currently broken, but this error message seems misplaced so I'm still reporting it. This isn't the error we normally get for read-only mode, temporary server errors, or 404. Perhaps something is bubbling up from lower-level code without being caught, like maybe something having to do with favorite or ignored tags? (Of which I have none, by the way.)
